Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Equilibrium Studies of Solution-Phase Self-Assembly
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division and the Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering Program, Douglas Vander Griend of Calvin College will study the step-by-step thermodynamic processes that lead to solution-phase self-assembly of supramolecular structures. To characterize such ensembles of molecules, equilibrium-restricted factor analysis (ERFA), a powerful mathematical deconvolution technique, is used on composite data. Specifically, raw absorbance data from a UV-Vis spectrophotometric titration can be modeled in order to ascertain 1) the number of distinct chemical species in solution, 2) the spectroscopic signature of each, and 3) the equilibrium constants for the reactions between them. In all, three supramolecular systems will be studied using this technique. Obtaining such detailed information about a system without having to chemically isolate any of the components will unlock the key design elements for various types of synergistic molecular organization. The broader impacts involve training undergraduate students, networking with collaborators and other researchers around the world to share knowledge about various forms of factor analysis, and making Sivvu?, the software program for ERFA, available through the internet.

Whether it is inside our bodies, as part of nanoscale machines, or as effective chemical sensors, molecules do some of their best work as ensembles; however, characterizing groups of various types of molecules and how they cooperate with each other is no straightforward task. Sometimes each component can be isolated and studied, but usually this method is unhelpful for sorting out how the components interact. This research project seeks to address this challenge by collecting data on a system as a whole, and then using powerful mathematical techniques to model the different molecules according to precise chemical laws. The specific focus is to probe how biomolecules rearrange themselves in solution and how smaller molecules join together to encapsulate target molecules. This research should help scientists understand how molecules specifically interact with each other in larger groups, and could lead to ways to design systems to perform useful technological functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In their pursuit of useful formulations, scientists often encounter ensembles of molecules; nanomachines, biochemical processes, self-assembling supramolecules, and catalysts just to name a few. The potential for innovation is staggering, but matched by the difficulty in characterization. More and more it is not sufficient to chemically isolate each compound to study it because it is the interaction between the compounds that is key to the functionality of the system.

Our work to develop and extend the techniques and methodology for characterizing complicated systems of multiple molecules that interact in synergistic ways has involved three main endeavors.

    1) Develop the techniques to consistently measure the wavelength dependent color of a complicated system of molecules over a range of compositional ratios.

    2) Study various interesting systems from our lab and from collaborators around the globe.

    3) Refine the mathematical methodology for modeling the data from these systems to achieve the most accurate and useful chemical parameters, with uncertainty ranges, for characterizing the system. Then make it available to the world through the internet.

We have accomplished the first feat by integrating a small robot known as an autotitrator with our spectrometer. Given the lack of mechanical precision and reliability, this took several years longer than expected. Such is science. In the meantime, we continued to collect data on a plethora of chemical systems.

These past few years we have focused on three main systems. 1) The encapsulation of cations in a ~90-piece self-assembling molecular cage called a nanojar (Figure 1). This system was developed by Prof. Mezei at Western Michigan University. While we have made progress on characterizing the nanojar assembly, we still have work to do. However, once we succeed, it will be the most complicated self-assembly system every studied with this approach. 2) The characterization of a solution-phase chiroptical molecular sensor for ferrocene, a special electron-rich molecule. Collaborating with researchers at the University of Pavia, the delicate interactions between the sensor molecule and ferrocene were captured well by our method for analyzing solutions. The research also led to some beautiful cover art as shown in Figure 2. 3) The folding of small peptides into a hairpin (figure 3). This project was largely conceived and carried out by undergraduates, who synthesized all of the peptides and measured them using a new CD-spectrometer (also funded by NSF). Their work almost complete, they are both headed to graduate school in chemistry next year.

The third part of our work involves the development of the mathematical and computational methods to carry out the modeling of these complicated systems. We have been executing the deconvolution of composite data, that is values that represents the entire system, into smaller sets of values that represent the individual components for over a decade now. Figure 4 depicts how this is accomplished. The key is the restrictions that are placed on the smaller matrices (non-negativity, unimodality, mass balance, and equilibrium). This makes the calculations more difficult, but also renders the results much more useful to scientists. Optimizing our protocols is a time-intensive endeavor that was championed by Beckman Scholar Nathanael Kazmierczak, an undergraduate who earned the prestigious Beckman Foundation award for research at a predominately-undergraduate institution like Calvin College. While we had already written a computer program to accomplish the analysis, he finalized the optimal methodology. This involved hundreds of thousands of simulations to convincingly nail down the impact of various options. Even more importantly, he set up high-through-put Monte Carlo simulations to refine our method for determining the error values associated with the output values from the modeling. This had never been done properly before as other researchers have relied on mathematical shortcuts to estimate the error. Nathanael’s prolific work will be chronicled in a series of five articles, coming soon.

With the fine-tuning of the method complete, our program for modeling complicated chemical systems is more useful than ever. We call it SIVVU, which is UV-vis backwards, because it starts with UV-vis absorbance data and works backwards to determine how the chemical system behaved so as to give rise to the measured data. This type of modeling is widely applicable in many areas of chemistry and so we have launched Sivvu.org – a website where researchers anywhere can upload their data and model it according to our research-tested algorithms. We still have much work to do to make it fully robust and operational, including moving the calculation node to a supercomputer so that rigorous error analyses can be handled in real time. Furthermore, it is my dream that Sivvu.org become a repository for all datasets of this type so that researchers, reviewers, and data miners can all take advantage of the information. That is part of what my future work will involve, and the reason that I look forward to applying for continued NSF funding.
